Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Ultrasound-Guided Vascular Access Techniques

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with healthcare providers as the unit of randomisation. The sample size was calculated to detect a significant difference in procedure success rates.

Participants.evidence: Participants were healthcare providers trained in vascular access, recruited from multiple hospitals.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group used real-time ultrasound guidance, while the control group used landmark-based techniques.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of ultrasound-guided techniques for vascular access compared to traditional landmark-based methods.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the success rate of vascular access procedures, measured immediately post-procedure.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a higher success rate (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with no severe complications.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under number NCT12345678

Funding.evidence: funded by the National Institutes of Health
